instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
No corrosion evident on board.

pp3v3_g3h 3.4v
ppbus_g3h 13.07v
pp5v5_s5 5.12v
pp3v3_s5 3.35v
pm_slp_s4_l 3.3v
smc_reset_l 3.4
all_sys_pwrgd 3.2v
pp5v_s0_fan_conn 5.1v
pp5v_s0_vcore1 5.1v
pp5v_s0_vcore2 5.1v
pm_slp_s5_l 3.3v
rtc_reset_l 3.1v
pch_srtcrst_l 3.1
[B]pch_intruder 0v[/B]
pm_slp_sus_l 3.3v
pp1v8_s0 1.8v
pp1v8_s0_pch_vcchda_f 1.8v
pp1v2_s0sw 1.2v
pch_hsio_pwr_en 3.3v


snow edition USB shows steady light till just after being delivered 20v
Still get current draw mostly 0.45amps with occasional second at 0.7amps

No video.

Wondering where to go from here.

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
"[B]pch_intruder 0v[/B]"
I suppose to be PCH_INTRUDER_L and must be high.
Check R1401 pin 1 voltage.
If present, check diode mode to ground at pin 2.

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
I must have made a mistake in measuring originally as R1401 pin 1 is 3.0v, pin2 is 2.8v
Diode mode to ground at pin 2 is 0.75v

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message: What is the final CPU core voltage?

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
PPVCC_S0_CPU 0.72v
PPVCCSA_S0_CPU 0.78v
PPVCCGT_S0_CPU 0v

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message: Check if there is external video present.

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
No external video. 
CPU 55centigrade

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
What said the client about history fault?

Try known good BIOS.

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
Client said simply stopped working.
I haven't collected a BIOS for an [SIZE=3]820-00923 [/SIZE]A1706  as yet and can't find one on this forum. Is there anywhere else I can go?

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
Try this one, as is.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1W-l9MXzQjDRcX3tIgWPRAMVhcYajjX8t/view?usp=sharing[/URL]

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
Ive tried the BIOS above but still no usb activity, video or spinning of the fans via the keyboard ribbon cable in the case.
Could it be lack of a clock signal or is that ruled out somehow? I have an oscilloscope

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
Can you check CPU core voltage on other similar A1706 board?

Do you get all voltages from page 78 on your board?
BTW, test the board alone on the desk; nothing more than charger connected.

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
I have no other A1706 board.
I will check page 78.
Yes Ive had the board alone on desk the whole time - just occasionally trying back in the case for benefit of fans but I suppose thats a bit optimistic!

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
PP3V3_SUS 3.3v
PP3V3_S4 3.3v
P3V3_S0 3.3v
PP5V_S0 5.1v
PP3V3_S4SW_SNS 0.1v
PP1V8_S4 1.8v
PP1V8_S3 1.8v
PP1V8_S0 1.8v
PP1V2_S3 1.2v
PP1V0_SUSFUSE 0.99
PP1V0_SUSSW 0v and next time I look 5v
PP1V0_S3 1v
PP1V0_S0SW [B]0v[/B]
PP5V_S4 0v and next time I look 5v

PP1V0_SUS 0v and next time I look 1v

PP5V_PMICLDO 5v

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
U8280 not mounted, normal missing PP1V0_SUSSW.

If U8286 is mounted, then PP1V0_S0SW muste be there; check in diode mode to ground.
Post U8286 voltages.

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
U8280 is not mounted.
U8286 is there, PP1V0_S0SW 1v with board powered ( but pretty sure read 0v before)

Diode mode
pin1 0.3
pin2 0.47
pin3 0.15
pin4 0.15
pin5 0.1v
pin6 0.1v
pin7 0.5v
pin8 0v

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
No need to check U8286 anymore, if you get 1V0_S0SW.

Just in case, check pins 19/20 voltage, of U3500 and UB700.

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
U3500
pin19 5.1v
pin20 5.1v

UB700
pin19 5.1v
pin20 5.1v

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message: Try heat test on CPU and RAM...

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
What? Take up to 100centigrade? or reflow temperature?
For the cpu should I heat the heatsink itself to keep it even?

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
Remove heatsink!
No need to melt the balls.
Just try to burn eventually accumulated crap underneath; or expect some internal reaction.
No more than 180-200 degrees, for 15-20s.

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
No luck, no image on test screen, no usb activity. Is all hope lost?
Student customer concerned about loss of data for university work so what percentage chance do you think [B][FONT=arial][SIZE=3]076-00236 hardware might pull data off? Ofcourse I would have to locate that hardware.[/SIZE][/FONT][/B]

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message: If no damage on SSD area, you should be able to recover data over Lifeboat connector.

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
Student client cant pay for data recovery so fixing the board is the only way.

Is there any further hope for the logic board? (other than a much needed donor ;)
Should the cause of the periodic increase in current draw be looked for or is it normal behaviour?

Some further advice appreciated!

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message: 6 days later. I was hoping for an opinion whether there was any future hope for this board. Customer has become disillusioned and wants the macbook returned.

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message:
This looks like lost cause, sorry.
People who buy Apple machines, should understand how important is to make backup on external storage device, or Internet.

threads.title: 820-00923 20v 0.45 amps to 0.7 amps no video
threads.message: Sadly I wont even get a donor board out of it. Did you put down the [SIZE=4]0.45 amps to 0.7 amps as not worth investigating - is it normal or something trying to switch on but switching off?[/SIZE]
